001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on int coordinates in 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6 dimensions and
005 * an int for state; here, points are considered toroidally wrapping, where the wrap happens at a power of two that is
006 * no greater than 1024. This implementation stores 6 caches of 1024 numbers each, where each cache is used for a
007 * different dimension, and XORs the values along with the seed before running through Thomas Wang's integer hash.
008 */
009public class TorusCachePointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
010
011    protected final int[] cache;
012    protected int wrap = 63;
013    public TorusCachePointHash() {
014        cache = new int[6 * 1024];
015        setState(42);
016    }
017
018    public TorusCachePointHash(int state) {
019        cache = new int[6 * 1024];
020        setState(state);
021    }
022
023    public TorusCachePointHash(int state, int wrapAt) {
024        cache = new int[6 * 1024];
025        setState(state);
026        wrap = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo(wrapAt) - 1;
027    }
028
029    @Override
030    public void setState(int state) {
031        this.state = state;
032        SilkRNG rng = new SilkRNG(state);
033        for (int i = 0; i < cache.length; i++) {
034            cache[i] = rng.nextInt();
035        }
036    }
037
038    @Override
039    public void setState(long state) {
040        this.state = (int)(state ^ state >>> 32);
041        SilkRNG rng = new SilkRNG(state);
042        for (int i = 0; i < cache.length; i++) {
043            cache[i] = rng.nextInt();
044        }
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Thomas Wang's 2002 integer hash.
049     * @param x any int
050     * @return a usually different and very-scrambled int
051     */
052    public static int determineInt(int x){
053        x += ~(x << 15);
054        x ^= x >>> 10;
055        x += x << 3;
056        x ^= x >>> 6;
057        x += ~(x << 11);
058        x ^= x >>> 16;
059        return x;
060    }
061
062    @Override
063    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
064        return determineInt(state ^ cache[(x & wrap)] ^ cache[(y & wrap) + 1024]);
065    }
066
067    @Override
068    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
069        return determineInt(state ^ cache[(x & wrap)] ^ cache[(y & wrap) + 1024] ^ cache[(z & wrap) + 2048]);
070    }
071
072    @Override
073    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
074        return determineInt(state ^ cache[(x & wrap)] ^ cache[(y & wrap) + 1024] ^ cache[(z & wrap) + 2048]
075                ^ cache[(w & wrap) + 3072]);
076    }
077
078    @Override
079    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
080        return determineInt(state ^ cache[(x & wrap)] ^ cache[(y & wrap) + 1024] ^ cache[(z & wrap) + 2048]
081                ^ cache[(w & wrap) + 3072] ^ cache[(u & wrap) + 4096]);
082    }
083
084    @Override
085    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
086        return determineInt(state ^ cache[(x & wrap)] ^ cache[(y & wrap) + 1024] ^ cache[(z & wrap) + 2048]
087                ^ cache[(w & wrap) + 3072] ^ cache[(u & wrap) + 4096] ^ cache[(v & wrap) + 5120]);
088
089    }
090}
